channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: "Freakonomics》（《怪诞经济学》）是这一波图书浪潮的顶点，它承诺对传统智慧所忽略的事物进行奇特而严谨的分析。这种方法很有趣，但已经失宠👇。
item.description:
“Freakonomics” was at the apex of a wave of books that promised a quirky—yet rigorous—analysis of things that the conventional wisdom had missed. The approach was fun, but has fallen out favour https://t.co/OhQj6nXyBG 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 不久前，咨询业看起来还坚不可摧。但自 19 大流行病以来，咨询业的增长一直萎靡不振，有三个问题使其复苏变得更加复杂 👇
item.description:
Not long ago the consulting industry looked indestructible. But growth has been soggy since the covid-19 pandemic, and three issues are complicating its recovery https://t.co/kFcyOEmOkF 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 许多人都认为穆萨卡（moussaka）--由味道浓郁的肉馅、沾满油的茄子和香浓的焦糖酱组成的邋遢方块--是希腊的国菜。它进入希腊美食的神殿，是传统如何形成的一课 👇。
item.description:
Many consider moussaka—sloppy squares of richly flavoured mince, oil-slicked aubergines and indulgent béchamel sauce—Greece’s national dish. Its entry into the pantheon of Greek gastronomy is a lesson in how traditions are forged https://t.co/HTXLBE0GvT 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 自罗伊案终审以来，美国最高法院将首次审理堕胎案件。一个问题可能会主导整个对话 👇
item.description:
For the first time since ending Roe, America’s Supreme Court will hear an abortion case. One question could dominate the conversation https://t.co/1uAYilk4qZ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 如果穆罕默德-穆斯塔法（Mohammad Mustafa）真的开始解决巴勒斯坦人的无数问题，这位新任命的总理或许还能赢得一些支持。但合法性和振兴将来自投票箱，而他尚未确定选举日期👇。
item.description:
If Mohammad Mustafa actually begins fixing the Palestinians’ myriad problems, the newly appointed prime minister might yet win some support.

But legitimacy and revitalisation will come from the ballot box, and he is yet to set an election date https://t.co/IHPCOIOpdd 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 美国的购房者和卖房者在目前的方式下并没有为佣金支付合理的价格。而与一群中介达成的和解协议并不能保证他们将来会有这样的机会👇。
item.description:
Homebuyers and sellers in America do not pay a fair price for commissions under the current approach. And a settlement agreed with a group of agents offers no guarantee that they will have such a chance in the future https://t.co/PZILcE21ju 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: "有一种说法认为，曼德海峡（Bab al-Mandab）得名于那些在试图穿越海峡时被淹死的人所流下的眼泪。"海峡是一个咽喉还是一个渡口，取决于你是有货物需要守护，还是一无所有。摘自 1843 年杂志
item.description:
“One theory is that the Bab al-Mandab got its name from the tears shed for those who have drowned while trying to cross.”

Whether the strait is a chokepoint or a crossing depends whether you have goods to guard, or nothing to lose. From 1843 magazine https://t.co/kUMJulrJ03

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 摄入更少的卡路里可以防止衰老 👇
item.description:
Eating fewer calories can ward off ageing https://t.co/zJ5ohzhxVk 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 电动汽车正处于肥胖流行病的风口浪尖 👇
item.description:
EVs are in the middle of an obesity epidemic https://t.co/rEbVSTqWP8 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 发音、重音和节奏很少有人教得好 👇
item.description:
Pronunciation, stress and rhythm are rarely taught well https://t.co/gLodU0EIQP 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 供需失衡使酒店经营者可以将每晚房价提高到远高于通胀率的水平，而不必过于担心顾客的流失。
item.description:
An imbalance between supply and demand is allowing hoteliers to raise nightly rates well above inflation, without worrying too much about putting off patrons.

This is turning luxury hotels into a lucrative asset class https://t.co/VSstBQQtyx 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: "尤瓦尔-诺亚-哈拉里（Yuval Noah Harari）在一篇特约文章中谈到人工智能时说："我们刚刚在地球上遇到了一种外星智能。"我们对它知之甚少，只知道它可能会毁灭我们的文明。
item.description:
“We have just encountered an alien intelligence, here on Earth,” Yuval Noah Harari says of AI in a guest essay. “We don’t know much about it, except that it might destroy our civilisation” https://t.co/MUVLpl1sSC 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 最新研究显示，全球最便宜的 20 座城市中有 9 座位于亚洲。但亚洲大陆也有一些世界上最昂贵的大都市👇。
item.description:
Nine of the world’s 20 cheapest cities are in Asia, according to new research. But the continent is also home to some of the world’s most exorbitant metropolises https://t.co/2No7HGmhKf 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 没有一套完美的财政规则。但在英国，政府只要克制住篡改规则的冲动，就会向前迈出一步👇。
item.description:
There is no perfect set of fiscal rules. But in Britain, the government just resisting the urge to fiddle with them would be a step forward https://t.co/l3kk8d8IWl 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 今年早些时候，人们普遍认为乌克兰战争正逐渐陷入僵局。现在看来，这种看法是乐观的。
item.description:
Earlier this year, a common view was that the war in Ukraine was settling into a stalemate. That now seems optimistic https://t.co/XbGsA80XYQ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 英国擅长让外国人尽快适应经济、社会和文化生活。它（至少在这方面）是世界其他国家的典范👇。
item.description:
Britain excels at getting foreigners up to speed economically, socially and culturally. It is (in this respect, at least) a model for the rest of the world https://t.co/50B1lyN0sS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 西方必须认识到将其非洲政策外包给不认同其价值观的国家的危险；非洲国家也应了解让自己成为别人地缘政治游戏中的棋子的风险👇。
item.description:
The West must see the danger of outsourcing its Africa policies to countries that do not share its values; and African countries should know the risks of letting themselves be used as pawns in someone else’s geopolitical games https://t.co/hewIufyaTk 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 三本书解释了为什么它很重要--而且很容易丢失 👇
item.description:
Three books explain why it matters—and can easily be lost https://t.co/P1UNT18pwu 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 随着加沙战争的继续，以色列有可能更加深陷于几十年来扭曲其社会、毒化其对外关系的占领之中：
item.description:
As it continues its war in Gaza, Israel is at risk of becoming even more deeply mired in an occupation that has warped its society and poisoned its foreign relations for decades: https://t.co/xtYcBwPk92 pic.twitter.com/7qBWgByBtd

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 生成式人工智能可以从根本上改变法律实践。如果它能在 20 秒内完成十几名律师每人需要 50 小时才能完成的任务，那么大型法律公司为什么还要继续聘用几十名律师呢？ 👇
item.description:
Generative AI could radically alter the practice of law. If it can do in 20 seconds a task that would have taken a dozen associates 50 hours each, then why would big legal firms continue hiring dozens of associates? https://t.co/1pcruZOBtw 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 肥胖薪酬差距比以前想象的还要严重。这种差距对男性和女性都有影响，而且受过良好教育的人的差距更大。
item.description:
The obesity pay gap is worse than previously thought. It affects men as well as women, and is wider for the well-educated https://t.co/hFVtTVahnO

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 向初学经济学的人推荐五本书 👇
item.description:
Five recommended books for those starting to study economics https://t.co/zURPq2VRuo 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 五篇介绍如何简单而出色地写作的文章 👇
item.description:
Five texts that explain how to write simply and well https://t.co/IXO6q1DLug 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 非洲在很大程度上依赖于为数不多的海底电缆。它们也异常脆弱👇。
item.description:
Africa depends heavily on its few submarine cables. They are also unusually vulnerable https://t.co/agzLfFmIOb 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 印度政府为阻止 "黑钱 "流入政界而发行了 "选举债券"，印度公司通过 "选举债券 "在政治捐款上花费了数亿美元。但显示债券购买者和接受者的数据却引起了轩然大波
item.description:
Indian companies have spent hundreds of millions of dollars on political donations via “electoral bonds”, which the government launched to stop the flow of “black cash” into politics. But data showing the bond purchasers and recipients have caused a stir https://t.co/wQd6zacyQn pic.twitter.com/twLDatJAjh

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: "印度政治、经济和社会生活中的断层线正在不断扩大，"@艾亚尔-亚米妮在一篇特邀文章中写道。她呼吁所有印度人参与到维护国家民主的斗争中来。"他们未来的繁荣取决于此"。
item.description:
“Fault lines in India’s political, economic and social life are widening,” writes @AiyarYamini in a guest essay. She calls upon all Indians to take up the struggle to preserve democracy in the country. “Their future prosperity depends on it” https://t.co/bgrk8vbRY8

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 特姆优会赢得美国购物者的青睐吗？在本周的 "Money Talks "播客中，我们将问亚马逊和 Etsy 等公司应该如何担心中国电子商务巨头🎧？
item.description:
Will Temu win over American shoppers? This week on our “Money Talks” podcast, we ask how worried companies such as Amazon and Etsy should be about the Chinese e-commerce giant https://t.co/MJQ8Ac4xCA 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 世界不同地区人们思维方式的差异似乎正在扩大 👇
item.description:
The differences between how people think in different parts of the world seem to be widening https://t.co/QcKvPFBexa 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 大多数服用抗抑郁药物的人并不需要这种药物。找出真正需要抗抑郁药的人，并让其他人摆脱这种药物👇。
item.description:
Most people on antidepressants don’t need them. Identify those who really do—and wean other people off them https://t.co/wfyiHe0hJr 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: @madrid_mike 说："认为移民是拉丁裔选民的决定性问题 "是错误的。他加入了我们的 "制衡 "播客🎧。
item.description:
It’s wrong to assume “that it’s immigration that is the defining issue for the Latino voter”, says @madrid_mike. He joins our “Checks and Balance” podcast https://t.co/R1LAutmXZs 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024
